title: As a Christian why does it feel like our Christian music is so cheesy and cringeworthy? - Quora

response.answer_text: If its true, its because pop is so cringe worthy. I think in order to narrow in the question itself, its necessary to get some perspective and perhaps some self-reflection: What specifically in the music are you taking issue with? What about the lyrics or the music?Can’t that be said of pop music too?How much Christian music was produced last year?How much got radio play?What percentage of that are you taking issue with?Can you name 5 tracks that you are taking issue with?I feel like any critique of a genre of music is a little half-baked until one reflects on those questions or questions like them. Its just far to easy to cast stones, if you don’t have any specifics, its not particularly helpful or insightful. Also, Taylor Swift it right: Haters gonna hate. Its true of lots of art and creativity. Besides, this from Need to Breathe is pretty good:  Theodore Roosevelt, also had his own version of “Haters gonna hate” which is this: The Man in the Arena

I think I can help with this question, but if you don’t mind, I’d like to address it from the perspective of how the music business, religion and human nature are intertwined. I’d also like to go at it only addressing the “cheesy and cringeworthy,” styles because there’s plenty of high quality Christian music on the rosters and in the archives. I get it! It’s not cheesy and cringeworthy because it’s Christian. Why is this a real thing, and why is it predominant in the Christian broadcast and distribution industry? Human Nature, Creativity and Creative Environments: The most creative and innovative musical personality types are very often the outliers, the ones who push the boundaries, the ones who are insatiably curious about what lies beyond the threshold of the unknown, the ones who are always reaching for more. They can often be the lonely genius types as well. None of these personality types are well suited for restrictive religious environments. Naturally, the lonely, genius types are neither attracted to nor comfortable in an intensely rich, community environment. Naturally, the outliers are not searching for a tribe, a people, or a closely knit community environment. Naturally, those who are insatiably curious about what lies beyond the unknown won’t find a happy home in many churches. The questions about what lies beyond the unknown have very clear and precise answers that are expected to be agreed upon and adhered to. A high proclivity for pushing the boundaries is not a good fit for many church environments. Music and Religion: As far back as we can go, there has been music and religion and the two are intertwined. As often as not, there is a tension between the music and the faith. The inspired and revered great composers of 16th century Europe were often sponsored by a branch of the Roman Catholic Church. In those traditions, there were specific chord voicings that were permissible and others that were strictly forbidden. Major and minor triads as well as dominant seventh were permissible while extended chord voicings such as sixth, major seventh, ninth and thirteenth were strictly forbidden on the basis that they were far too sensuous and seductive. It was believed that these voicings would subliminally draw congregations into sin and out of devotion to God. In some of the Old Order Anabaptist traditions, hymns and the human voice are highly cherished while instruments of any kind are entirely forbidden. I once had a friend who was an upper middle age Old Order Mennonite. Sweetest gal you’d ever want to meet. Upon learning I was a musician, Sweetest Ol’ Mennonite gal told me of the most heartbreaking moment of her life. The elders of her church had decided that instruments in the home would be forbidden, so her father loaded up the family piano and took it to the pawn shop. She’d grown up to love spending hours upon hours every week, playing the piano with the family gathered around, singing old hymns. It was her greatest joy in life. Gone. Sweet Ol’ Mennonite gal carried the pain for the rest of her life. Sad. Renowned guitarist, singer, songwriter, Phil Keaggy, describes himself as, “Too worldly for the faithful, too faithful for the worldly.” Phil has spent his life’s work and natural gift standing at the boundary between creative innovation and the belief system he ascribes to and promotes. Moving across the continuum, I’ve seen many instances of a strained relationship between “the music and the message” (the sermon). In many of these circumstances, the music is described to as the “fluff, the candy,” or the unfortunate necessity of serving as a “drawing card” to bring people in so that they might hear the message. In one particular example, I have a close friend who is a Music Professor, Orchestra Director and very talented violinist who played voluntarily in a church worship band where the worship leader opened the service by praying that the congregation would not hear the music so they could focus solely on the message. Most in that congregation were strongly agreed with the worship leader’s sentiment. My friend was deeply hurt by this event. I also know many musicians who side wholly with the worship leader in this. At the far opposite end, we see the African American Pentecostal traditions of the deep South where the music is everything. The worship band plays for hours as the congregation dances and parades around the church expressing their joy in the Lord. As a musician myself, the first time I saw one of these services, my brain silently shouted, “Now THAT’S my kind of church! I’ll post a link at the end of this answer. Music, Church and Business: It’s no secret that religion is a hotly contentious topic and music can be a somewhat contentious topic. We’ve all heard about the family rule that dictates, “NO politics or religion at Holiday meals.” Whatever may be the money driven excesses of the Christian Music Industry (and they are certainly part of the equation as are addictions, fraud and sexual escapades), let’s give ‘em a break at least enough to say, “they gotta eat.” To do that, they’re between a rock and a hard place. The imperative becomes, first and foremost, how not to offend, followed by how to survive in business, followed way behind by how to create the best possible, most innovative and inspiring music as an art form. Tough call. Really tough call. So they feed us highly inoffensive “food for the soul.” Baked potatoes, mashed potatoes, fried potatoes, stewed potatoes, potato soup, potato salad, potato casserole, potato’s au gratin, potato cakes, twice baked potatoes, crispy potato wedges. Oh, and not to forget a favorite popular dish, “Cheesy and Cringeworthy,” potatoes. For their own survival, they have to draw the line on anything that might trigger “food for the soul sensitivities or allergies.” If my overview has left you feeling a little vehement or glum, please enjoy this short excerpt from a worship service featuring The Campbell Brothers. Campbell Brothers

Other answers described very well the reasons that make not just Christian music, but virtually any large-scale, massified musical industry sound superficial, cheesy and facile. That’s especially in the last decades, when that issue became even more pressing as access to music became increasingly popular - and pop-like -, enhancing the demand for easy, catchy, almost instinctively exciting melodies that can be rapidly consumed, discarded and replaced in a mass production system. That’s not just about Christian or more broadly religious music, it’s a feature of these times. However, I must say that there is no way that I think one can describe all Christian music as “cheesy and cringe”, especially if you consider the history of classical music since its very beginnings, which actually took place inside churches and monasteries. In fact, a disproportionately large proportion of the best pages of the history of Western music (including most of its early evolution and the creation of a technical study of music), as well as of the best musical artworks throughout the long history of classical music were deeply associated with Christian themes - and not just in the past, even nowadays some of the greatest classical pieces have been composed with some religious, more specifically Christian purpose in mind, as several works of Arvo Pärt, the genius El Niño of John Adams, and many others. The collection of best classical works is full of masses, oratorios, choral chants, requiems and other sacred works. Here are just two examples separated by almost 300 years, Dixit Dominus by Händel and the Requiem by Timothy Hamilton:   But the important role of Christian music is not just restricted to classical music. The African-American negro spirituals, as they used to be called, are almost universally about Christian religious themes and are anything but cheesy. Lyrics and melody-wise they are often very deep and captivating, musical works of real artistic value. I don’t know much about other genres, but I’m pretty sure that other excellent works can be found as part of the legacy of Christian-themed musical pieces.  But I honestly wouldn’t expect to find them in the “usual” sources that most people get stuck at and think they couldn’t know any better: the disposable output of a musical industry that depends increasingly on fleeting successes, things like hits, virals, instant celebrities, and so on. Dig a bit more, and you’ll find a lot of Christian music that is not cheesy nor cringy. Whether it’s secular or religious, sacred or profane, most of the mainstream massively popular music will probably sound a bit superficial and cheap if you put too much thought into it. Maybe you’re expecting to find apples amidst the oranges. Just saying. ;-)

Oh, it doesn’t just feel like it, it is cheesy and cringe-inducing. I suspect the reason is economics. The music business is a business. You have to identify a market and sell to it. Christian music isn’t created because of some upwelling of Christian faith, it’s created because Christians are willing to pay for it. Because of that, it doesn’t make sense for it to contain any specific doctrinal details. It’s going to be as non-denominational as they can make it. It’ll be full of hearts on fire, and love for Jesus, and the feeling of being loved by the god, but it’ll all be very superficial and artificially emotional. Seriously. Listen to any of it. Is there anything in there that isn’t vague? Is there anything that corresponds to a specific doctrine that’s unique to your flavor of Christianity? That’s what the market will buy, and that’s what it gets.

Hello writer, I have at times felt the same sentiment. I believe there are reasons. Songs are spiritual and our sensitivity to the Holy Spirit can make them seem ‘chessy’ or ‘cringe’ if we have a hardened heart, it can make us more critical of human imperfections in their art and expression. But sometimes over-hearing (hearing it too much) or trying to make songs produced or sound a certain way to fit a style, can make it ‘cheesy’ as it is done for popularity or man’s ‘sheepish’ nature. It is the same with heavy metal or rap though. I used to love heavy metal music, now it just sounds ‘cheesy’ and ‘predictable’ and ‘false angst’ to try to hype up the crowd. I had a dream some years ago and Jesus sung to me. I woke up and fell from my bed to the floor weeping for 3 hours. His voice goes through you and you feel His love wash over your soul. His voice echoed and reverberated through the heaven and was perfect in sound. His words are living and you feel His words. I have never heard a song being sung on this earth that has affected me like hearing the songs that Jesus sings. Shalom

Because it is supposed to be worship but comes across as entertainment and like we are trying to imitate the vibe of the world. This isn’t the way Christians are supposed to live. It’s like we have no identity, direction and personality of our own. The singers come across as secular artists because their whole personalities are formed by sin and the world rather than God and it trumps any of the lyrics they sing- in fact it’s at dissonance with the words they sing. I saw this movie called Margo who would get out and energize a crowd with his singing and preaching. Then it would show him through the week taking drugs, having sex etc. I am not saying all artists are this blatant in their sin, they in fact are probably worse, because they probably only commit socially acceptable sins like having sex with their girlfriend or drinking alcohol, which is legal etc. etc. But they think that no one can see what they are really like as people just because they are Christian singers, but who they are is more obvious than the lyrics they sing. If they were truly connected to God, their songs and music would have a completely different sound than the world. It wouldn’t touch our emotion, but it would touch our soul, it wouldn’t feed our flesh but would feed our faith. I personally don’t experience Christian music like this. I don’t mean to sound judgmental because we are all sinners, but Christ removed our sin and gave us a new spirit. It’s the new spirit we should be sharing.

It doesn’t. At least not to me. The Christian music that is getting played these days at our parish here in a rural spot of Switzerland is neither cheesy nor cringey. It is just mostly old! And some things just cannot improved upon. Try improving Swiss Chocolate! The old works of European sacral music is something of timeless beauty. The old, traditional Catholic hymn book is still in use here, and those old hymns are actually those, which the faithful are able and willing to sing along with. Those “modern” compositions all too often try to cover up their lack of beauty and ambiance with complicated arrangements and hard to sing notes. Churchgoers often wish a soothing atmosphere in Mass or service, not some “upbeat” tunes no one knows and you need to attend a workshop for being able to sing along. Here, at our town of 7000, our parish church of some 400 seats is packed with people to capacity and beyond twice in December, when the traditional Advent concert is being held. Mostly old music, sometimes seldom played, not all from Europe, either. A well-played pipe organ, the original baroque instruments, our local choir, reinforced with a few professional singers for the solo parts and you as a parish give some of the best Christmas presents for your community. People from all walks of life attend, even the younger crowd sets foot into the church. This is of course a superb “commercial” for Midnight Mass on Dec 24th. There is nothing cheesy about those beautiful old Christmas songs, and no one is going to cringe when the whole building sings “Silent Night” in tune, with a candle in their hand. Some things are best left the way they are. The mere fact that something is new does not make it necessarily better, and not everything that is old is automatically outdated. Christianity by definition has a conservative trait to it. Some teachings are not going to change, while the community wants to remain Christian. There is nothing like age-old music that was played in the same way some 500 years ago to underline this timeless-ness of the Church - and God.

I imagine there are countless ways to answer this question, but I'll give my take. Somewhere in Christian music history, the Christian music industry must have written a policy that says, “our lyrics always have to provide clear-cut answers to spiritual questions.” While we can provide answers as God's people, I think many Christian songs are written like a Brady Bunch episode, where all problems are solved before the closing credits roll. It's OK to ask honest questions without providing answers in every song. Traditional worship songs can be awesome, but people also want authenticity.

We tried to take pop culture, slosh some vague and generic inspirational lyrics in, and pass it off as music. The problem is that the world, in general, doesn’t appreciate Christian music. Therefore, the budget becomes substantially smaller. Therefore, the quality becomes substantially worse. I personally think most popular Christian music is indeed cringeworthy and cheesy. There’s a Blimey Cow parody of how to write a worship song that is disturbingly accurate. However, there still are artists and arrangers and writers who truly want to glorify God and write solid, meaningful, doctrine-filled music. I recommend the Pettit Team (Heart Publications), the musical groups from West Coast Baptist College and Lancaster Baptist Church, and SoundForth for incredibly meaningful, beautiful, deep and precious music.

Oh, it’s not just your imagination! There is some really solid Christian music out there, but there is some that is total fluff, with nothing in the way of redeeming qualities. (I’m a pastor with 30ish years of experience, so I can say I’ve pretty much heard it all!) On of my favorite new Christian songwriters is Stuart Townend (note: no ‘s’ in the last name—there’s an actor named Stuart TownSend.) He writes some songs that you would swear are very old hymns, with really solid theology and beautiful music. “How Deep the Father’s Love for Us” is a favorite of mine. There are other really good Christian artists out there. It’s just a matter of sifting the proverbial chaff from the wheat, y’know?

Probably because you are listening to contemporary Christian music which is derivative of derivative music that is derivative of cheesy and cringe-worthy garbage. If you want to listen to Christian music and you want it to be good you need go no farther than your standard hymnal. There are some hidden gems in there that are harmonically complex as well as lyrically deep and meaningful. Just a Closer Walk with TheeA Mighty Fortress Is Our GodIt Is Well With My SoulHow Great Thou ArtMay the Circle Be UnbrokenGreat Is Thy FaithfulnessI’ll Fly AwayBlessed Assurance If you don’t like those then you can look to classics such as: Hallelujah Chorus by HandelJesu Joy of Man’s Desiring by Beethoven

Because it’s always trying to enable something that is beyond its own scope - namely worship. Also, Christian musicians are always (rightfully) fearful of being distracting or misleading. In this sense, the art must never attain the status of its subject - that would be idolatry. Hence, Christian music - even the very best, like Bach - is always unfulfilling. The insufficiency of our music-making can serve as a reminder of the greatness of its origin to which we attempt imperfectly to return it. Music always fills us with longing. It never satisfies. Not until we are included in the true source of its transcendent beauty - and that will never be in the stuff itself.  As a trumpet player, I always struggle not to cry while playing as the most profound cadence in western harmony precedes the coronation chorus.

Cause it is, man. Good Lord. I’m not saying all GodRock is bad. Just most of it. Take Rend Collective, the GodRock band I’ve got the most experience with. It’s dull, flabby, forgettable, and violently sincere. With more banjo than thought, it sounds like Mumford and Sons meets It’s Everyday Bro. I haven’t got further than about 10 seconds into on of their cuts without spluttering. To anyone out there who’s looking for some seriously good Christian music, check out The Life of the World to Come by the Mountain Goats, which is frankly excellent. Or, for that matter, Thomas Tallis.

Because a lot of it is absolute drivel. Contemporary Christian pop is musically and theologically bankrupt (Trust me on this; I’m trained in both) Happily, that stuff is only a small percentage of Christian sacred music. Familiarize yourself with the classic hymns (the English ones are particularly good), the great sacred choral works by Bach, Mozart, Rutter, Brahms, Mendelssohn, Faure, Duruffle, and Beethoven. Check out motets by Thomas Tallis, Palestrina, and Welliam Byrd. Listen to Gregorian chant, and American shaped note hymns. If all you’ve heard is the so called “praise music” favored by post Vatican II Roman Catholics, and Evangelicals, you don’t even know a small fraction of the sacred musical repertoire.

Back when I was a Christian we called this 7–11 music. Seven words repeated eleven times. The tunes are catchy in a simplistic way, and the lyrics are often turned into dog whistle phrases. “My life is in you, Lord, my strength is in you, Lord, my hope is in you, Lord, in You, it's in you. See? Simple, one syllable words. It's geared for indoctrinating children and keeping Christian adults high on religion. They love it, but yes, to the rest of us it does sound pretty cheesy.

Well, because sometimes it is. There's no denying some music just sounds plain cheesy, and Christian music mistakingly falls into that category sometimes. As a fellow Christian, I will be honest and say that I've only ever liked a handful of “Christian” songs. As long as you always have and keep God in your heart, the type of music you listen to really doesn't matter. It's ok (and understandable) not to always dig that type of music.

Incidentally, many of the “Christian” Record Labels are owned by the major record labels; Universal Music Group, Sony Music Entertainment, and Warner Music Group. These labels have one mission, to make money selling music that will be bought. They couldn’t care less about the content. They will sell whatever sells, regardless of how cheezy, meaningless or incoherent. Just look at top 40 radio.

Quite a bit of it is as you describe, with some bright spots that are far less derivative of pop music. Though I grew up listening to pop music in the '80s, which still sounds great today. I also enjoy music from the '60s and '70s. As great as the music is from those eras, when I listen to it now, it's crystal clear that they focus on, and sometimes idolize, the values of the world that are the opposite of what God wants us to focus on: our lives dedicated as a sweet-smelling sacrifice to Him. With praise music, I know that the message is about God, how to live for Him, or how He empowers us to His glory. I still enjoy “retro” pop music from time to time, but my awoken ears don't enjoy it as they did back then when my heart was empty (because the Holy Spirit was not yet dwelling there).

You’re not listening to the right Christian music. Try Vivaldi, Mozart, Bach, Beethoven, Fauré, or even Copeland or Bernstein (who were not actually Christian). It never hurts to broaden your perspective in any area, and often the results are delightful.

We have a few Christian stations here in Australia and whenever I’m flicking around the stations on my car radio it’s always quite apparent that I’ve tuned into a Christian station by the music. Most songs are well constructed but seem to have been put together out of some sort of Lego “construct a song” box. And the lyrics are a dead giveaway, they mostly seem to be along the lines of “give me the light, I have lived in darkness”… “where is the light?” .. “I long for the light”.. Sounds like they need to stock up on LED flashlights. Good for a chuckle, though.

Not all of it is. It does seem like the radio stations play the cheesiest and most cringe worthy of all. I think that some Mercy Me stuff is really good. The Newsboys have some really good stuff, and Todd Agnew, whom I seldom hear on the radio any more will blow one’s socks off with the depth of his lyrics.

There’s lot of different music out there, even Christian music. Much of pop music in general is cheese and cringe. In my experience getting outside of the mainstream is where the better Christian music is, and lest we forget the classics and classical, which is fantastic. But the problem is pop sells, and that’s why it’s out there.

If you’re talking about Pop Christian music, then I agree. But if you’re talking about classical music that was written for the Church, or some timeless hymns, then I have to disagree. Speaking as a Wiccan, I vehemently assert that Christians have the best music and cookie recipes EVER. They have us beat hands down on that one.

Why don't just pray to God to show you Christian music that isn't cheesy and cringe? If for whatever reasons God's saying no to your prayers, then I have some favorites I would like to share. Check out Lauren Daigle  Amanda Cook  Lauran Horii

I love computer and video games. But I don’t limit my choice of music to the theme from Super Mario Brothers (although I admit I’m addicted to Smooth McGroove’s acapella versions of game music). Is it a measure of your faith to listen to only to music that limits its themes to Christianity? Can you not “make a joyful noise until the Lord” without specifically mentioning him by name? You should try.
Most Christian music is annoying because it simply recites the same bland words about worship without telling the story of why God is worthy to be praised.

Because most of it is. Like other music industries, mainstream Christian music is out to make a buck, so they appeal in content and musical style to their main demographic, just like other industries. So if Chris Tomlin and 3 chords sells, they will sell it until it doesn't.

Well, you can always go back to Johann Sebastian Bach. That’s always fun. While not Christian nor religious myself, a notable innovative musician in the circle of “Christian” music would be Todd Edwards. His music is cheesy in a way, but in a good way. Though he’s American he’s much more popular in UK music circles I guess.
Mainstream Christian music is “cheesy” and “cringe” because its an accurate reflection of the state of the modern church. Besides that, old Christian music is pretty hardcore.

There are only so many ways you can combine three or four chords and phrases like “praise him and his holy name.” It’s even worse when the praise band has a 45-year-old bass player who wears shorts during services.
Because it is. even in the good old days, most of it was ripped off. And even the original stuff was hokey to the extreme.
Try listening to Misty Edwards or Lacey Sturm.
These are some of my faves…I hope you all enjoy! If not…i still will!  Francesca Batastelli …I.love!  My recent fave #2 Ryan Stevenson   My Ringtone! #Warrior  My 2015 autoreplay Oceans  My ultimate!
